lines.text: Hey you bastards, I'm still here.
Blame is for God and small children.
[Papillon is contemplating a daring leap from a cliff to escape]

[the plan]
It seems so desperate. You think it will work?
Does it matter?
If you're going to catch leprosy, it's better to catch it from money than from people.
I accuse YOU... of a WASTED LIFE!
Guilty... guilty... guilty...
Remember what the chicken said to the weasel?
If he was a healthy weasel, the chicken didn't get a chance to say anything.
We're something, aren't we? The only animals that shove things up their ass for survival.
A temptation resisted is a true measure of character.
I know you, you're Degas. You're a very intelligent man!
Thank you. I seem to be known in all the wrong places.

[to Dega]
Me they can kill... You they own!
Make the best of what we offer you, and you will suffer less than you deserve.
Put all hope out of your mind. And masturbate as little as possible, it drains the strength!

[Briefly examining Dega in a prefunctory manner]
You're fine. NEXT!

[Walking away]
Must be better than I feel.

[Briefly examining Papillon]
You're in wonderful shape.
How do you fail an examination like this?
NEXT!
If I stay - here in this place -I will die!
How did you know I have dry leprosy, that it isn't contagious?
I didn't.
You keep your money and you take me with you.
No.
I'm the only one who can get you out of here.
You're...

I know. I'm a queer, a fairy, a poof, huh? But there's one thing you forgot. You may have been framed, as you say you were... but I wasn't. Between the two of us... I'm the one who's killed a man, not you.
Okay.
We do a lot of smuggling here. We raid the mainland. We steal boats. When an outsider comes in we generally kill him, as a security measure.
That makes sense.
Well... a man of Christian understanding.
You're Louis Dega. I'm Clusiot. How come you ended up in a place like this?
Favouritism.

[to Papillon upon his release from solitary confinement after five years following his second escape attempt]
Your five years in solitary confinement are at an end. You've paid part of your debt to France.
We all have sensitive spots.

[to Papillon upon his release from solitary confinement after two years following his first escape attempt]
Your term is completed.
Well, it now seems quite possible that until we get to a decent jail with bribeable guards, I may stand in some need of... rather close physical protection.
That depends on how long you want to live.
For a long time.
Then you got a problem.
Well, I presume that you have some, uh, goals, some particular need that outrates all the others. I mean, if so... may I aslk what it is?
Money!
For what?
Escape.
Very good. You keep me alive until we land in Guyana, and I'll underwrite any escape you care to arrange.
Escape for me, not for us!
Oh, of course. I, I, I...
[laughs]
. I have no intention, uh, of even attempting to escape - ever!
Done!
Forget France and put your clothes on.

[to Papillon as he is marched aboard ship bound for penal colony]
Papillon! Papi! You'll be back, Papillon. Don't worry, you'll be back.
No, you won't.
